docs.lead_paragraph: The new owners of the Pawtucket Red Sox, a Class AAA team that has sent many future stars to the majors, said they intended to move the club to Providence.
docs.abstract: New owners announce plans to relocate Pawtucket Red Sox, AAA baseball team that has been a fixture in the Rhode Island town for decades; residents decry planned move to Providence, saying it will have devastating psychological impact on Pawtucket; team is among most celebrated in the minor leagues and has sent many future stars to the majors.

docs.lead_paragraph: After arguing their case yesterday before the arbitrator IRA JAFFE, shortstop JOHN VALENTIN and the Boston Red Sox agreed to a one-year contract worth $2.673 million, up from $637,5000 last season. Valentin had asked for $2.75 million after hitting .298 with 27 homers and 102 r.b.i., and Boston had offered $2.2 million.

docs.lead_paragraph: Every schoolboy and schoolgirl in New England knows it. They presumably learn it before they learn any other history -- the Mayflower, Plymouth Rock, the Boston Tea Party, the Minutemen, Lexington and Concord, the Battle of Bunker Hill. They know that the Boston Red Sox have not won the World Series since 1918. But do they know that the historical plight of the Red Sox goes deeper and back even further? Their lesson for today, then, is to learn, memorize and write 10 times that the Red Sox have not finished in first place a second successive season since 1916.

docs.lead_paragraph: ON a wintry night during the Jazz Age, a man and his flappers hailed a cab and were wisked out to Fenway Park. The driver, a wizened old fellow who thought he had seen everything, watched incredulously while the man placed a key in the door of the stadium and ushered the girls inside. Ten minutes later, the passengers returned. ''What the hell was that about?'' the cabbie said. ''Just wanted the ladies to see my ball park,'' the man answered.

docs.lead_paragraph: The addition of Kevin Mitchell to the Boston Red Sox received mixed reviews today in the camp of the Yankees, one of the teams that will be most directly affected if Mitchell has remembered to bring his home run bat back from Japan. "It will be interesting to see how they fit all the bats into the lineup," David Cone said before the Yankees lost to the Cincinnati Reds, 6-1.

docs.lead_paragraph: Boston Red Sox pitcher VAUGHN ESHELMAN burned his hands early yesterday while trying to extinguish a fire in his hotel room in Fort Myers, Fla. The fire started when his wife, JULIE, was trying to warm a baby bottle for their 2 1/2-month old son, EVAN, with a candle. A wash cloth became ignited by the flame and when the fire spread, Eshelman tried to smother it with his hands, Red Sox officials said. He suffered second-degree burns. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: Infielder WIL CORDERO, obtained last month by Boston from the Montreal Expos, avoided an arbitration hearing yesterday by agreeing to a $1.85 million, one-year contract with the Red Sox. The deal, more than a fivefold increase over last year's $335,000 salary, also includes $300,000 in performance bonuses. (AP)

docs.lead_paragraph: 'Reversing the Curse' 'Inside the 2004 Boston Red Sox' By Dan Shaughnessy 260 pages. Houghton Mifflin. $23. 'Emperors and Idiots' 'The Hundred-Year Rivalry Between the Yankees and Red Sox, From the Very Beginning to the End of the Curse' By Mike Vaccaro 364 pages. Doubleday. $24.95. For Red Sox fans, the approach of opening day of the 2005 baseball season means a chance to replay the miraculous events of last year: not just the team's first World Series victory since 1918, but with the sweep of the final four games of the American League Championship Series, the greatest comeback in baseball history and over their most hated rivals, the Evil Empire itself: the New York Yankees. For members of Red Sox Nation, 2004 was the year that put an end to decades of misery and humiliation, an end to the Curse of the Bambino, an end to 86 years of boneheaded plays, bitter losses and buckets of bad luck -- not to mention baleful memories of Babe Ruth, Bucky Dent, Bill Buckner and Aaron Boone.
docs.abstract: Michiko Kakutani reviews books Reversing the Curse: Inside the 2004 Boston Red Sox by Dan Shaughnessy and Emperors and Idiots: The Hundred-Year Rivalry Between the Yankees and Red Sox, From the Very Beginning to the End of the Curse by Mike Vaccaro; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Readers' reactions to two new books about the Yankees-Red Sox rivalry will depend on their team allegiances....
